The deterioration of both our memory and our entire entity are subjects that fascinates me.From the moment we are born, we begin to form connections and construct our personality; at a very minimal level, of course, but this portion of our life is utterly vital to our eventual being. As we grow older, we begin to learn to talk, walk and do other common practices that we take for granted as we age. As is made note of by the protagonist within Still Alice, from our earliest days, we are processing information at an exponential rate, absorbing the visual and verbal contexts and features of our environments to improve our knowledge of the world. It's incredible that children can form such a strong personality at so young an age; even if they have barely been alive a year, but they can still (physically) enunciate their emotions and thoughts. Perhaps they can get up on their own two feet and walk across a room. It's amazing.I watch the members of my family and examine their behavior. My sister is 9 years of age, an amateur gymnast, quite possibly an intelligent individual, full of life and vitality and absolutely in love with One Direction and Taylor Swift. Her personality is still being crafted day by day, and she is yet to find her special something; the thing that a kid or a teenager finds that becomes their unique attribute. Mine is a love of film and scoring. All the same, she is young and with the world ahead of her, much like my brother and I. I am the eldest; the one who dares to go out into the world first. To make the intrepid charge into adulthood before either of my siblings. It scares me as I don't have another family member of comparable age who has already ventured out into the dark and mysterious world. I'll be the first of my parent's offspring. That makes me nervous.My siblings and I are all building our memories, and have just initiated the construction of our individual spirit. I build memories every day; whether it be the first kiss I experienced (an absolutely disgusting display of inadequacy in the area), the first film I remember seeing at the theatre, the first time I had a sibling born and was no longer the only child, or the first time I endured death within my immediate family. I remember the day my grandfather passed away vividly. It was a school day, and I'd had a poor time. I had felt alone even though my friends were around me. I was struggling in maths, as I always did. I wasn't able to concentrate. I hated myself, and I hated everyone around me; I despise days where I can't hold my attention. I was frustrated with the world. But then I came home, and my father informed me that my grandfather had died, and it put into perspective how naive and slight my problems were. That whilst I was complaining about not being able to figure out an algebra technique, one of the people instrumental in shaping me into the person I am today slipped from this planet of ours. All these memories form me into the human being that types here today, and they form the initial establishment for my thoughts on the world around me.Much as Boyhood reflected on the wonder of discovery and building memories, Still Alice provides an analysis, albeit less refined, on the condition of demise. Our protagonist, the titular Alice, is diagnosed with early-onset Alzheimer's disease at the age of fifty. She is a respected linguistics lecturer at Columbia University, and possesses a healthy marriage and three children who have turned out rather favorably. As we meet this woman, she is a beaming example of intelligence and energy. She possesses a smile that lights up a room once she steps in it. But she forgets a word or two here and there, and begins to lose her way whilst she goes on runs. The initial displays of deterioration are obvious and slightly forced, but they lead way to moments of emotional resonance. Alice's plight is one that we understand, and her denial, guilt and frightened states ground her in a reality that is as tragic as it is painful to watch.There are moments of dramatic tension which are unnecessary and lead credence to the idea of "Hollywood-ising" something. A potential suicide thread is completely without substance and eventually results in a rare moment of comedic relief for the audience, the direction of the culmination of this concept proving ill-handled. That said, there are moments where Still Alice shines. But more importantly, it absolutely rivets. I was not only astonished by the acting prowess on offer, but also scared by the intensity and verisimilitude of the performances. Lead actress Julianne Moore won the award of Best Actress at the Academy Awards recently, and whilst she should not have bested Rosamund Pike in the category (Gone Girl deserved at least one award!), she most certainly deserves the commendation she has received. Her restrained authenticity and range maintains an audience's attention, even in the most baffling, boorish or excessive of moments. It is her who grounds the film and allows it to mesmerize.The movement from a jubilant woman to a human of disabled status proves highly effective in provoking the kind of emotions the film targets. It may shove its manipulative hands down your throat, but that's not to discount the impact of those same prodding hands. It's heartbreaking to witness the decline of such an intellectually advanced woman; it's harrowing to know that even the brightest and most intelligible of our society can be brought to their knees by the very object of their competence and dexterity. The mind is home to our most astounding thoughts and concepts, but it, like all other features of the body, is a muscle that is capable of corruption. The disease that Alice is diagnosed with reminds us of the frailty of mankind, and it made me scared for my future. To lose what makes me me? To forget the names of my hypothetical children or my hypothetical wife? To lose the ability to verbally communicate my thoughts and opinions on various subjects? What can be more frightening than slipping into an abyss which contains only you; where you can not be the person you once were? How can anyone live this way?Still Alice doesn't necessarily answer that question. Its ending hints towards the eventual resolution that Alice would face if the film were to continue on past its ending point, but it never shows it. This is the most alarming of all questions asked throughout; where would she end up in the end of it all? Still Alice makes it clear that there is only ever one outcome in relation to her disease, and that is death. The worst thing is that it's more than just a shot to the heart, a knife across the throat or a sudden heart attack. It's prolonged and slow. Every child's worst nightmare is that of dying in a painful way. We're all frightened by the idea that we could be tortured to death, or shot in the head. That we could be hit by a car. That the plane we're travelling in could fall out of the sky. But none of those seem even marginally comparable to the physiological suffering caused by slowly being internalized. Still Alice tackles this melancholic topic with a heavy heart and affects one for doing so.I could discuss at length the value of the cinematography in such a pivotal context, but all I'll say is that it is astounding. I'd like to end this review by stating that I don't know when I'm to die. I don't when I'm to take my final breath. My future belongs in the hands of the universe, and whether I shall die with a family surrounding me or in a lonesome street all alone, I shan't know until it is all imminent. And when the time comes, I'll want but one thing; the ability to be able to look back and appreciate. To embrace my failures and my successes throughout my brief stint on this planet. To acknowledge all those who have paved my way. I'll think about my parents; my brother and sister; my first girlfriend and all those subsequent; my pets; my Year 9 religion teacher who taught me to be myself; my friends; my family. I'll want to remember the first time I watched How To Train Your Dragon and cried at its beauty. I'll want to remember the first time I witnessed Jack grow up in The Tree of Life. I'll want to remember the first wails of agony and aggression within James Horner's score to Avatar. I'll want to remember the first banal screams of life that my theoretical son or daughter delivers. I'll want to remember all the small things that made life worth living; the rain pelting my roof whilst I type at my computer, intent on writing the greatest review of my life; playing in my sandpit as a child; imagining building rockets, creatures and cities as I explore my backyard; running around with my dog Stella (yes, she was named after Interstellar); hugging my mother and father after a long day of school; savoring the sweet taste of banana cake whilst watching a television show. But most of all, I want to remember my grandfather. I want to remember his joyful face. I want to remember his ironic nature. His bawdy jokes. I want to remember the smile that covered his face whenever my family would come and visit him and my grandmother. I want to remember. Still Alice reminded me of the importance of memories. Even in its most frustrating moments, this is beautiful film.

Don't let the rating fool you; I don't want you to see this movie. It's well made and very, very powerfully acted, yes. Julianne Moore knocks it out of the park and Kristen Stewart (yes, THAT Kristen Stewart) gives a very heartfelt performance. So if you're into acting give it a go, I suppose. Be forewarned though: this is the most soul-crushingly depressing movie I've seen in years. If your idea of entertainment is watching a brilliant, vibrant Professor of Linguistics deteriorate into someone who can hardly formulate a one-word sentence, then by all means go see it. ****SPOILER ALERT****And of course she has the rare Familial version of Alzheimer's Disease, so she's passed the gene on to one of her daughters (which means her daughter is 100% going to contract the disease). This movie was so profoundly sad that I was desperately hoping the poor woman's suicide attempt was successful, even though she didn't even know what it was she was doing.

After hearing the hype of Julianne Moore and her incredible performance in this flick, I thought to myself maybe I should check it out. Boy was I happy that I did, I saw probably one of the strongest performances by a woman in film. There were times during the movie where I felt sympathy for the character because by her portrayal of the character I could tell Alice was just not herself. There were times the film might have been a little slow for me, but that was expected, so it did not take me out of the movie. It was a tale of a woman who was changing by a terrible disease that does affect many today. It was sad, emotional, and quite inspiring. The run time of the movie could have been longer, but it did not affect my overall thought of the film itself. I would recommend this film in general, but you can choose to watch it on the big screen or not. It is not the greatest movie theater experience one could have, unless you do like the theater for whatever reason.4.4 / 5 Stars

Not a bad movie, but it left little impression on me. The strongest part of this movie is its acting - Julianne Moore indeed gives a touching, sincere and powerfully emotional performance as the ailing linguistics professor, Alice.To be honest I found the film rather too predictable to be genuinely enjoyable. While I appreciated learning about Alzheimer's and felt it was a good depiction of a woman's slow descent into sickness, I didn't feel enough of a dramatic pull in the storytelling to keep me fully interested and engaged. I saw almost everything coming miles before it happened. And not only that, but there aren't that many interesting things happening in the movie in the first place. Alice loses her position at the university. Alice gives a talk at an Alzheimer's foundation. Alice tries to commit suicide but is predictably stopped by her daughter coming home.I don't know. Maybe I've just seen way too many movies for my own good, but I found Still Alice a tad on the boring side. Don't get me wrong - it's a touching and poignant movie about a very important disease that more people should be aware of, and it is not without its own form of subtlety and sophistication, but I didn't find it as engaging and provocative as I had hoped it would be.Still, not at all a bad movie, one that comes with my recommendation. I think Alzheimer's should receive far more attention, so kudos to the filmmakers for addressing this unpopular disease.

"Still Alice" is the sort of film one feels almost obliged to like. It features an acting Tour De Force by it's star Julianne Moore, it deals with the tragic effects of Alzheimer's Disease on the individual and their family, and it is based on a best selling book. The screenplay is solid and the supporting actors are all faultless. So why did I find it so very unremarkable and so predictable and why did I leave the cinema so unmoved? Much has to do with the subject itself; so much has been written and spoken about this awful disease that one hopes that a movie like this will provide a fresh insight into its ravages but it basically tells you everything you already know. Plus so many movies nowadays are aimed squarely at the heartstrings that the audience sometimes becomes 'all cried out' from seeing so much abject misery and tragedy on the screen. If only someone, somewhere would write a genuinely good comedy but, alas, it seems that is a lost art!

After having read, and loved, the book by Lisa Genova, I highly anticipated seeing the movie adaptation. I was not disappointed. I was concerned about the medium getting it right. A first-rate treatment of Alzheimer's afflicting a successful linguistics professor who has it all: a perfect family, great job, and happy life. It begins with a perfect recreation of professional, upper-class, intellectual New York which then gives way to an unstoppable illness which touches everyone in differing ways. Great acting from all and a tone which nicely balances between sentimentality and reality without going too far to any extreme of emotion.

Okay, let me just say, Julianne Moore's performance is brilliant in the film; she captures the fear, sadness, helplessness and perseverance of an Alzheimer's patient with tact. Other than Moore's acting, 'Still Alice' felt quite bland and underwhelming to me. It failed to give us more insight into the lead protagonist, and gave us almost no insight into the lives and minds of her loved ones. When someone is afflicted by Alzheimer's, it's his/her loved ones who suffer more. I mean, the person exists, but all the memories connecting him/her to others ultimately vanishes, and that is torturous to the people around. The film is too linear and paper-thin; the theme had so much potential, but it's completely squandered. All of the characters just merely exist that you almost feel nothing for any of the characters. Other than Alice's speech in the second half ,there wasn't a single moment or aspect which made me connect to the characters.With much more needed depth, the movie could have been as terrifying as the disease itself, and may have given us some idea as to how people cope with it. Now, it's just one of those disease-movies which will be easily forgotten (except of course, for the fact that Moore finally won her Oscar for this).

Julianne Moore owns this role with such care and precision playing a woman suffering from Early-Onset Alzheimer's Diseaseit's an Oscar-worthy performance of such professionalism the middle of the film actually brought a few tears to my eyeswe need to know that no one should have to go through this disease alone or feel the slightest bit isolated, and Alice makes it quite clear that she isn't suffering, she is strugglingAlice wont let this sickness beat her to the punch and she remains as strong and as hopeful as can beit may affect the rest of her family but they are willing to meet her halfway knowing what's to come as every bit of Alice's memories, qualities that make her special, and her identity disappearnoting is worse as uncertainty and not knowing yourselfKristen Stewart surprisingly has a lot of depth in a film like this, she and Moore are golden as mother and daughterAlec Baldwin as the husband is just fine and so is Kate Bosworth as the other daughterat times we may not remember everything we've done or the people we've met but that doesn't erase what makes us the people we turn into, so many traits and characteristics will always be with us no matter how old we get or how much time passesif there's a cure out there for holding onto what is most important then we will find it one of the best movies of the year and a stunning turn for Julianne Moore

I imagine it must be very hard to make a movie about Alzheimer's. It seems to always have such a straightforward trajectory, with small memory slips, then a doctor's appointment/diagnosis, then a gradual declining until the person basically doesn't know who their loved ones are anymore. There's only so many places you can go with a movie about someone with Alzheimer's. In addition, it's hard to prevent a movie like that from becoming overwhelmingly depressing. It's just such an inherently sad thing to happen to someone.Still Alice does get a little sentimental in parts. I wasn't super fond of the first act or so of the movie, just because it went exactly like I thought it would, and all those early signs of Alzheimer's seemed a little overwrought and obvious, although, again, that's something that comes with the territory, not necessarily a mistake the filmmakers made. But everything proceeded in a standard direction. Also, there's a scene where Alice gives a speech, to lots of applause from people. I complained a lot about this when it came to The Theory of Everything, but I eventually realized why it was so much more effective (I teared up) in this movie. First of all, it didn't come at the end as a dumb way of showing the audience how brave and wonderful she is, or something (like Stephen Hawking). And second, it was acknowledged that ultimately, it was one of the few happy moments in a long road ahead, that Alice wouldn't even remember the speech after some time. The speech wasn't reductive. It was a genuine triumph for the character, especially with her neurologist there (a character I, strangely, really liked).The film overcomes most of the sentimentality thanks to the supporting cast and a general light touch in some scenes. There's some humor that goes a long way to preventing the mood from turning oppressive, although I would've liked even a little more humor, without seeming too artificial.The parts I really enjoyed of Still Alice, though, were the things that set it apart from other standard Alzheimer's narratives. I found it extremely interesting that Alice would use her linguistics skills to devise ingenious ways to remember things, and that's what made it all the more heartbreaking when she failed. Another dimension I really liked was the revelation that Alice passed the disease on to her kids (at least Anna). I would've actually liked if the movie did more to delve into Alice's guilt about that, because that was an interesting facet I haven't seen in movies like this before.Maybe one of the best parts of the movie was the character of Lydia, who was played surprisingly excellently by Kristen Stewart. The thing I liked about Lydia was that she was super unsentimental, still getting angry at her mom for being condescending about her dreams and reading her private diary, but also had a ton of love for her mom, and a lot of hidden heartbreak. One of my favorite scenes in the movie is when Lydia apologizes to her mom for getting angry earlier and asks her what it's like, having Alzheimer's. It's refreshing to hear Lydia genuinely curious and not annoying or sad about it - she never breaks down and cries or anything throughout the movie. But that scene does a great job of exemplifying the duality I mentioned; though she doesn't get melodramatic about it, you can see her struggle not to freak out as Alice explains her memory loss in-depth.Then there's the ending. I wasn't expecting that to be the last scene at all, so when it flashed to the title card afterwards, it seemed abrupt to me. But I do kind of like that it ended there. I like that it didn't end with Alice dying (whether from the disease or from suicide), or with her finally forgetting who Lydia was, or something. I like that the movie gave us a large, comprehensive snapshot of Alice's struggles with Alzheimer's, but I'm also glad it didn't try to cover so much ground that it took us to the end of her journey. If Julianne Moore wins the Oscar tomorrow, I'll be pleased.

The story is absolutely heart-breaking, but what makes it feel real is the characters' reactions to the disease, with some surprises hidden in the plot. While this will always be Julianne Moore's show from start-to-finish, Kristen Stewart is surprisingly good in a supporting role.
Julianne Moore's heartbreaking performance is the best reason to see this film. The symbolism is rather heavy-handed, but easy enough to ignore whenever she's onscreen.
Difficult to watch, but it handles the emotional material well while Julianne Moore gives one of her best performances.

On a trip to California to see her actress daughter Lydia(Kristen Strewart) and to speak at a conference, Alice Howland(Julianne Moore), a university professor in linguistics, trips over a line or two in her speech. Concerned that this could be a symptom of something more serious, she sees a medical doctor who after running a wide variety of tests, diagnoses her with early onset Alzheimer's disease. To make matters worse, the disease is genetic, putting her three children at risk of developing it.While "Still Alice" may not exactly excel in showing Alice's deterioration from her point of view, that's really not the point of this otherwise fine movie. What the movie is much more interested in a keenly perceptive way is the dynamics of the Howland family that is so overachieving that one of the daughters cannot just give birth, she has to have twins. Okay, okay, I know it does not work that way but it could look like that to an outside observer but not to Lydia who is comfortable with opting out of the race. However, for her mother, who remarks at one point that she would have preferred cancer, that is not an option, having overcome so much already in her life. Frightened by what she witnesses at a nursing home, not the state of the patients but the lack of visitors, she Rube Goldbergs her own euthanasia. In the meantime, Alice takes the opportunity to reconnect with Lydia who she had otherwise been at odds with before it is too late.
Julianne Moore for the win!!! What a great movie. What a brave performance.

Still Alice is a story of a linguistics professor named Alice, played by Julianne Moore, who finds out she has a form of Alzheimer's disease. The movie shows how it takes a toll on her and her family. It is heartbreaking to see how it affects Alice because she values her intellect. Her family must find ways to connect and help her. Julianne Moore does a fantastic job showing how the disease impacts someone over time. Kristen Stewart plays one of her daughter's and the movie does a good job showing their relationship. I thought the ending finished abruptly and the look of the movie was just okay. But that could be because of the source material. I give it a 4/5.

Amazing! Definitely a tearjerker but so raw and I feel like my emotional capacity expanded just from seeing this film. I think the camera work and acting coalesced in a very powerful way. Highly recommended!

Get ready for a gut punch. This is about a highly intelligent linguistics professor (Julianne Moore), who notices that she cannot grasp the perfect word during a couple of conversations/presentations. She goes in for a diagnosis, only to be given the tragic news: it's early-onset Alzheimer's disease. Talk about putting your problems in perspective. This is a movie where you slowly watch an incredibly clever woman's brain slowly deteriorate, and it is heavy and affecting. Personally, this had an additional layer in that I know that there is a history of this disease in my family, and boy, did it hit home for me. This movie is anchored by a positively brilliant performance from Julianne Moore. She has always been a great actress, usually appearing in supporting character roles, but here, she is given a wide range of emotions to hit, as she makes her way from high functioning to barely the same person. She is front and center gives a raw performance, and I don't think there is a surer lock at this year's Oscars, she is going to win. Speaking as someone who has memory problems, this is scary, and you are constantly worried for the next time she is going to have a "moment". You cringe for this woman, and it is heartbreaking at practically every turn. At its core, this is ultimately a disease movie, which is to be expected if you read the plot summary. I uttered "UGH" at least a dozen times, as there are many instances where there is a lapse of her fragile brain breaking. But like most disease movies, I have no inherent desire to ever rewatch this again, as it is not a good time, much like that cancer movie that gets released every two years. It's hard to watch a movie that's setting you up to feel so depressed, and while it is all very well done, you kind of know what you're getting yourself in for, and in many different ways, I view this as this year's Rabbit Hole. This is all about a woman trying to keep it together while ultimately resigning over to becoming an empty vessel, and if you can handle that, by all means, give this a watch for a tear-jerking performance by Moore
Amazing performance by Julianne Moore. She is at her best when she is not saying anything at all... her eyes say it all. She will def win an Oscar for this, a long overdue one, btw.

Every once in awhile I find myself watching a movie and thinking "I knew it wasn't going to be an easy one to watch, but what am I? Masochistic?" Such was the case with this well made and effective drama. It's not actually as much of a downer as one might expect, as the characters, including Alice, punch back at the hopeless diagnosis with a combination of life review, reflections imbued with gratification for a good life well lived, and spiritual/poetic inspiration. Julianne Moore's performance is flawless, even if I doubt most people would react to such a diagnosis with such a pragmatic nor in such a non- hysterical manner. However, the character she plays, a brilliant linguistics expert with a Ph D would seem more likely to take just such an approach. I might add that Alec Baldwin, who plays her husband, delivered an understated performance and was quite good as was Kristen Stewart, who set aside her usual tics and vaguely pissed off acting indulgences to play a convincing daughter at odds with her mother's expectations of pursuing a "normal" and responsible career. This is the best I've ever seen her in any movie in fact. Alice and her family are clearly at least upper middle class, which does not make the movie any less effective. However, the kind of material and familial support depicted is of course not always the case, in which such a shocking and grave diagnosis must be even harder to cope with. See this movie; it will win a deserved Oscar for Julianne Moore, but be prepared for a dark drama if you do so.
If Ms. Moore doesn't receive an Oscar for her stupendous performance, there is no God.
One of the most depressing films i have ever seen.....it is Julianne's all the way...

Driven solely by the character of Alice, there is nothing really remarkable about this film aside from the performance of Julianne Moore. There is a very impressive script written here, aside from a few questionable moments, but the plain camerawork and "television" feel the film has throughout, makes it a weird viewing experience to those were hoping for this story to be told in a "Hollywood" way. Does that hurt the film's story? No, but may make your mind meander throughout it's 102-minute running time. It's themes really does make you feel for these characters' emotions, and you will probably have a few tears trickling down your face, but what bothered me were the off-putting technical aspects. Overall, it is a very powerful and moving character study that is extremely well-acted and well-written. Those are two of the necessities in a great film, so I will give it a lot of credit for that, but there are a few undeniable set-backs, including an extremely abrupt ending. In the end, not having read the novel that this film is based upon, "Still Alice" is a moving picture that I highly recommend.

A tender, yet brutal, view of the onset and progressive nature of Alzheimer's Disease, "Still Alice" is another brilliant performance by Julianne Moore, surrounded by an equally brilliant supporting cast. The director uses editing and the camera to perfectly pace the film with occasional prolonged fuzziness to tie the viewer's observation of what is happening to Alice in tandem with the progression of the disease. It doesn't fall into a couple of very easily possible Hollywood traps during the film and, thus, stands out. It ends perfectly and respectful of the movie's theme. Why overrated films like "American Sniper" and "The Imitation Game" are nominated for Best Picture and "Still Alice" is not, in spite of the 10-film limit not being reached, is beyond me. It's certainly worthy of that consideration.

"Still Alice" stars Julianne Moore as a middle-aged woman diagnosed with the early onset of familial Alzheimer's Syndrome. She learns from her neurologist that the condition is hereditary and explains the uncommon occurrence of it for someone in her 50's. Alice even learns that she may have passed the gene on to her children unknowingly. The film deals with Alice's physical and mental breakdown from a distinguished linguistics professor at Columbia University to a shadow of her former self. Obviously, her condition deteriorates throughout the movie and affects everyone around her, including her husband (Alec Baldwin) and her kids. She starts forgetting simple things and arrives at a point where she can't even coherently speak. It is a very tragic film and not for the faint of heart. I felt that Moore did a remarkable job in the role and captures all of the aspects of Alice's personality amazingly. I believe her time has come, and if my sources are correct (which I have no reason to think they aren't), she will take home the Best Actress Oscar next Sunday. Kristen Stewart (Twilight) even does serviceable acting in the role of her daughter, however, Moore steals the show. Moore has waited a long time to be recognized to this extent by the Academy, but I feel this is her year and I see no reason to think she can possibly lose this race. Her role as Alice may well be remembered as the finest role she has ever played. This movie is excellent, and Moore steals the show ----------------------------------------------------------- B+

Still Julianne: The Great Actress Gives What May Be Her Best Performance YetYoung Critic1/29/2015Julianne Moore is one of the greatest at her craft. Her memorable performances in The Hours, Boogie Nights, and The Kids Are Alright, have found her a spot among the greats. Despite that, she's been denied an Academy Award. But with her latest turn in Still Alice it must be undeniable now: she's reached legend status. Still Alice is the harrowing story of a 50-year-old woman who is diagnosed with early on-set Alzheimer's: Alice Howland (Julianne Moore). Alice teaches linguistics at Columbia University, she is happily married with fellow medical teacher John Howland (Alec Baldwin) and has two daughters and one son. The oldest of her daughters, Anna (Kate Bosworth) is also married and is planning to have a child, Alice's son Tom (Hunter Parrish) is trying to settle down with a girl, and Alice's youngest, Lydia (Kristen Stewart), is looking to be an actress in Los Angeles. The film perfectly transitions the lovable Alice into her absent state. The experience is tough for the audience, and thus gives us the smallest of tastes into the tough lives that Alzheimer's victims and their families suffer. While all the praise has been going to Moore, both Baldwin and Stewart cope well with their roles. The reason that they may have been overshadowed is that the film is primarily focused on Alice alone, so the roles of John and Lydia are diminished. Nevertheless I was glad that Baldwin finally stepped out of his Woody Allen comfort zone, and Kristen Stewart left her Twilight days behind, which was the big surprise of the film. Previously it seemed as if she was an incapable actress with what we saw in Twilight, but in Still Alice she's given us all hope that she could make it as a serious actress. But of course we must talk about Moore. What I noticed was most admirable, was that most of her scenes were all one shot. I was especially marked with the scene in which she first goes to see her neurologist. The whole scene is a close-up on Moore and her mastery of her character was clearly defined there and then. Her simple stares and innocent repetition of sentences are heart breaking. However, the film doesn't want you to specifically feel pity for Alice, it wants you to experience her dismay in a realistic and objective emotional way. Driven by Moore's warm performance, the film is an example of how no matter how perfect and safe we may be in this world, we must cherish every moment as if it were our last. A-

+ "Still Alice" is a very difficult film to watch not because of the subject matter but because Julianne Moore inhabits the persona of Alice so you feel, and see, everything that is happening, and what will happen, to this woman.Alice Howland is a very successful linguistic professor at Columbia University in New York who has written books on language and traveled the world teaching it. She and her equally successful husband, John (Alec Baldwin) live in a brownstone in which they have raised their three children, now on their own paths, and have a summer home on the shore. In everyway she is successful as a professional, a mother and a wife.Very early in the film Alice, at the age of fifty, is diagnosed with early on set Alzheimer's which it turns out is genetic and there is a 50 percent chance of their children contacting it and, after testing, one of the children tests positive. The screenwriters/directors Richard Glatzer and Wash Westmoreland dismiss this angle in the movie instead concentrating on Alice and Moore comes through with a devastating performance. By the end of the film you will know what it means to have Alzheimer's, what and how it takes everything from you. Wordlessly, with a look, the changes in her face, the awareness of what she will lose before she loses it, is upsetting because we know what she had and she no longer does.The film rightfully concentrates on Moore but the screenwriters don't help her in not filling out the roles of her husband and children. We know her husband loves her because he tells her but Baldwin is a good enough actor to show us with little touches here and there. Her children, played by Kristen Stewart, Kate Bosworth and Hunter Parrish, are normal, well adjusted children which at times can drive a parent crazy and there is one scene where Moore uses that old line, "....I can because I am your mother," that has the audience laughing. The conflict between a mother and daughter is briefly touched on just as the sibling rivalry between sisters is but neither are fleshed out.The film is not all sadness and tears, with little bits of humor here and there, but we share the few triumphs Alice has along the way just as in two scenes we are afraid to breathe.For those who haven't dealt with Alzheimer's in their family this is a learning experience of what has happened with 45 million people in the world going through this debilitating disease and what their loved ones have to deal with.Julianne Moore has deservedly earned 4 Oscar nominations along the way and with her 5th in "Still Alice" she is deserving of getting that statue that has eluded her.

Proof that with a bit of talent and intelligence, even a disease-of-the-week TV movie can become a moving piece of quality (indie) drama. The finely judged script is lean enough so that scenes are never dragged out and the audience does not feel manipulated. Instead, it feels genuine and the emotions are well earned. And then there is Julianne Moore, who is effortlessly sublime and her performance is so well observed that her transformation as her character's early on-set Alzheimer's disease took over her mind will make you weep and your heart melts. She leads an exceptional cast who acts their collective socks off in nuanced and subtle manners, in particular Kristen Stewart who, in my opinion, was robbed of a nomination in the supporting actress category in the upcoming Oscars.

Alzheimer's is a terrible illness that affects millions of people. There is no treatment that can ease the pain and suffering from Alzheimer's from dementia, disorientation and language problems. Several movies have touch this subject, from On Golden Pond, The Notebook, Iris, Rise the Planet of The Apes.In the film Still Alice directed by Richard Glatzer and Wash Westmoreland tales the story of Alice Howland (Julianne Moore) a successful Columbia University linguistic professor diagnosed with early-onset Alzheimer's disease. She have a very supported family, from her husband John Howland (Alec Baldwin) and their daughters Lydia (Kristen Stewart) and Anna (Kate Bosworth). Is important to mention that her family have typical conflicts like any other family from Anna trying to conceive a baby to Lydia pursuing her career in acting in California. Alice keeps the early diagnoses of Alzheimer's disease secret from her family thinking that she can handle the situation. Until John and her decide on a family reunion to break the silence. Anna couldn't handle the news, but Lydia does, because her free spirit nature. For Alice Alzheimer's disease is coming to fast to ruin her success and also her normal and happy life. Her life deteriorate day by day, from loosing the ability to figure out locations, remember events and appointments to finally inability to teach in college. Alice event take her decease in a positive way, even joking to John how she have Alzheimer's disease and she is allow to forget thingsAlice decided to create her on personal way of remembering things, from creating notes on her phone to add her daughters names and birthdays and also important address and anniversaries. Unfortunately things starting becoming more problematic when Alice becomes more and more ill and also John gets an offer in Minnesota to run a medical department there. The family decides to take Alice to there summer house at The Hampton's so she can be away from the dangers of the city. There Alice reinforce relationships with John, but sometimes John is to busy to be with Alice. On the other hand Lydia develop new kind of ties with her mother because the book Angels in America. One of the most interesting aspects of the film is the use of the butterfly as a element of rebirth and also how Angels in America play another significant role in the story. How the celestial concepts and renaissance connects with Alice character and her unfortunate situation and how she it what it is no mater how lost she is because of the Alzheimer's disease.Julianne Moore perform a Oscar worthy role, perhaps one of her best.
This is not an easy film to watch. Sensitive and compassionate.

Featuring a leading performance from Julianne Moore said to be her all time best, Still Alice sounded like the film that would finally net her an overdue Academy Award.Still Alice is a thoroughly simple film. It doesn't have much narrative or too many characters and it moves at a slow pace which may irritate some viewers, but it is the greatest depiction of Alzherimer's disease I have seen in any film. This is because the story rests solely on two narrative elements: the concept of Alzheimer's disease and what it is to experience it. It doesn't progress in terms of story development all that much, but the way that it slowly intensifies more and more in its focus on the subject matter is very effective.Still Alice is essentially all about a woman named Alice with Alzheimer's disease and little more, for better and for worse. For most of the film, it is for the better because the simplicity in the film is one of its most beautiful elements. Focusing solely on its subject matter and main character while implementing in other characters as light subplots, Still Alice establishes their relationships with the main character as a way of establishing the damaging effect that it has with the other people in her life, such as her husband and her daughters. It touches upon the universe beyond Alice Howland, but the focus remains on her and takes a clever look into the way that she changes over the course of her mentality being damaged by it all. The emotional strength of the film is great because of the subtextual family elements as well as the elements regarding Alzheimer's disease which means that it goes beyond just the nature of its surface value subject matter. The script in Still Alice does a good job delving into the complicated themes of its subject matter and explaining its concepts to viewers in language which understands the complex nature of mental health but remains simple enough so that viewers are able to understand it. In keeping up with the complicated nature of Alzheimer's disease, the style of Still Alice moves along at a gentle pace but consistently cuts from one point in the titular character's life to the next though different points in time. The fragmented narrative gives viewers a sense of insight into what it is to experience Alzheimer's disease and it is consistent in doing so. Instead of coming of as choppy, the gentle directorial work of Richard Glatzer and Wash Westmoreland manages to ensure that the script is given the treatment that it deserves while the genuine feel of the film is appropriately atmopsheric, as well as being filmed nicely in a way which captures the claustrophobic mood of the main character.But there is nothing more key to the success of Still Alice than the leading performance from Julianne Moore.Julianne Moore is the entire reason that Still Alice is tied together as everything in the film rests squarely on her shoulders. With a career of four Academy Award nominations under her belt, she goes for a fifth in Still Alice which should hopefully be the one she wins for. While Julianne Moore is known for many complex characters she has played in a series of films, Still Alice is a simple film which requires her to play simply an everywoman. She plays Alice Howland as a strong and confident woman who really has her life shattered by the presence of Alzheimer's disease as she slowly attempts to deal with it in more hardcore situations. While Julianne Moore never lets go of her spirit and her likability, she gradually loses touch with her grip on memory more and more in a brilliantly realistic portrayal of the deterioration that is a painful reality that comes with Alzheimer's disease. Julianne Moore captures the suffering of the character Alice Howland flawlessy and develops incredibly well over the course of the story, and it is one of her finest performances ever simply because she strips away eerything that would make Alice Howland a character and emphasizes the saddening nature of her damaged humanity more than anything else. Julianne Moore has many scenes in the film where the camera focuses solely on her for an extensive amount of time without editing which shows her delivering many lines like monologues without her ever having a problem getting the character dead on in terms of physical instability and emotional trauma. She is surely the frontrunner for the Academy Award for Best Actress which is really long overdue as it is recognition she has deserved for a long time.Kristen Stewart also delivers a memorable effort. In one of her greatest post-Twilight performances, Kristen Stewart tackles the role of Lydia Howland really well. Going up against Julianne Moore, Kristen Stewart shares a powerful chemistry with Julianne Moore which brings a stronger sense of sympathy to the film as it touches upon the concept of a mother-daughter relationship in times of tragedy. For the Golden Raspberry Award winning actress from Twilight to face the challenge of standing up to five-time Academy Award nominee Julianne Moore only to succeed so incredibly is beautiful, and so Kristen Stewart's performance in Still Alice gives her more credibility than ever before.Alec Baldwin also makes a nice supporting effort, bringing a genuine sense of support to the suffering of Alice Howland which makes the film seem nicer by putting him in a restrained role where he faces the responsibility of caring for Julianna Moore's character. He shares a gentle chemistry with her. Alec Baldwin approaches the material in Still Alice in a very simple mannerSo while it remains a very simple film, Still Alice puts all the weights of its success on the shoulders of Julianne Moore who carries the film all the way with a beautiful and heartbreaking performance.
Brilliant movie! I thought it would be so depressing but it wasn't. It was real authentic and complicated just like real life. Julianne Moore was fantastic as was the whole cast. Great film

If you want to see a truly poignant and cinematically innovative film about a woman succumbing to early-onset Alzheimer's Disease, allow me to suggest the marvelous 2006 debut feature by Canadian actress-turned director Sarah Polley (only 27 when the film was released!), "Away from Her." Shot and acted with poise and restraint, starring the great Julie Christie ("Darling") and equally fine - but largely unknown outside of his native Canada - Gordon Pinsent ("The Shipping News"), that movie touchingly evoked the joy and pain of life and death. Based on a novella by Alice Munro, it was a perfectly crafted work of art."Still Alice" also has a literary source - the novel by Lisa Genova - and shares its main subject with that earlier film. It tells a similarly moving story. Unfortunately, its directors lack much of the grace and subtlety of Polley, and though Julianne Moore ("The Kids Are All Right") tries her (mostly) best in the lead role of Alice, she cannot make up for the rather ordinary and plodding way the script takes us through her journey. I usually admire Moore - she's one of the best actresses of her generation - but here she is unable to transcend the pedestrian soap-opera structure. So far, she seems to be favored in predictions for this year's Best Actress Oscar, but for me it is not a performance on the same level as that of the other nominees. She's good, but not that good.Moore plays a noted Columbia professor of linguistics who turns 50 as the film begins, then soon discovers that her recent wave of disorienting experiences is due to an inherited genetic defect that will quickly lead her inexorably into dementia. Before long, the sharp-as-a-tack woman we meet at the start has turned into someone who cannot find the bathroom in her own house. It's a tragic situation, made all the more so by the loss her family feels. Her husband, played by a distracted Alec Baldwin ("30 Rock"), is supportive but distant, unable to process the premature loss of his best friend; her youngest daughter, played by the ever-talentless Kristen Stewart ("Twilight"), struggles with the many unresolved issues we all have with our parents. There are other children, but they are not developed enough in the screenplay to have much effect on the story.It's sad. A lot of people cry. Alice speaks less and less. The camera isolates her with shallower and shallower depth of field. Surely we can do better than this shallow movie about such a devastating condition. And indeed we can: watch "Away from Her."

Alzheimer's...not exactly Saturday night movie fare but I went...somewhat begrudgingly..to see this film. You see, I, like many people, have seen Alzheimer's first hand. It's not pretty. It can be funny at times, but not pretty. But this story approaches this a little differently. The info: "Alice Howland, happily married with three grown children, is a renowned linguistics professor who starts to forget words. When she receives a diagnosis of Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease, Alice and her family find their bonds thoroughly tested. Her struggle to stay connected to who she once was is frightening, heartbreaking, and inspiring."And really this struggle to remain who she is/was, was interesting. It was heartfelt and definitely frightening, but I think it's worth a watch...especially to see Julianne Moore's best performance, maybe ever. She deserved an Oscar nomination for her portrayal. I'd say wait for this to come to streaming but definitely put it on your list to watch.

Still Alice has nothing to offer, though strives for passion and emotion, but only offers a scratch on the surface helping to shed no tears, but what lifts this film to attention is the nothing less than fascinating performance of Moore, who comes out triumphant in a portrayal that has me speechless and at a loss of words.Only this film comes with the sweet surprise of Kristen Stewart, who baffled with an excellent performance to match the presence of Moore, but also her portrayal of Lydia was the only aspect of the story to trigger my curiosity.Summing up: Amazing performances, less than mediocre storytelling.

It's long been said that Julianne Moore is long overdue for an Oscar. She's been previously nominated for Boogie Nights, The End of The Affair, Far From Heaven and The Hours, but she should have been nominated for Safe, Short Cuts, Magnolia, Children of Men, Savage Grace, A Single Man and The Kids Are All Right. Moore is an actress of uncanny talent and grace.That doesn't mean her performance in Still Alice is just overdue half-baked goods. As a Columbia linguistics professor exhibiting signs of early-onset Alzheimer's, Moore delivers a performance rich in detail, acting at its finest, alert to every nuance and feeling and ringing with truth.Moore's Alice Howland is an expert in her chosen field. She lives the life of a wife to John (Alec Baldwin), a biologist and mother to their three children, played by Kate Bosworth, Hunter Parrish and a wonderfully touching and vibrant Kristen Stewart. The family reacts in various ways to Alice's worsening condition, with the rebellious daughter---an aspiring actress who disdains her family, becoming her only willing caretaker. Even when Still Alice sometimes delves into cheap sentiment, Moore and Stewart are funny and superb.The film, like the book from neuroscientist Lisa Genova that inspired it, isn't exactly about the other people. It's all Alice. Through her mind and heart we see the world. The effect is earth-shattering, but not hopeless. Moore reveals a woman who doesn't yet know what will come with the dying of the life in her eyes. She can intuit from her children's reactions that they might inherit the illness, from her husband's decision to take up another job in another state and from her own decision to record a message to her deteriorating self in order to trick her later self into suicide.The film wisely refuses to hold Alice up as a specimen. We feel right along with Alice, something that must also be credited to the two men behind the camera. That would be directors Richard Glatzer and Wash Westmoreland (Quinceanera), who both wrote and directed Still Alice as Glatzer coped with the debilitating effects of ALS, a disease that ravages the body as mercilessly as Alzheimer's ravages the mind. Glatzer and Westmoreland, who married in 2013, make Still Alice deeply felt and personal. We feel the stakes they have in this story. Still Alice, bolstered by the brilliant artistry of Moore's performance, is an emotionally charged powerhouse of a film. It will take a piece of you.

"Movies are mechanisms of empathy," Roger Ebert didn't quite say.But this reviewer prefers the misquoted diction (provided by Anderson Cowan of The Film Vault.)When one asks, "Why watch Still Alice when it's only going to depress me?"There's only one legitimate response."It's a mechanism of empathy, dawg."Channeling an experiential river flow, the narrative spins the neurological waterwheel.Did I want to watch Still Al? No.Am I a smarter/better person following the experience? Absolutely.The purely objective form of personal growth? The viewer's exponentially more fluent in the Alzheimer's realm of modern medicine.The subjective forms? For one: The priceless merit of seeing a well-crafted, timely motion picture.Two: If your torso's peppered with shurikens, I'd hope it wouldn't come as a complete surprise.Likewise, if my demise arrives on a tidal wave of death stars, what's to stop me from running around in a circle and screaming obscenities until the official end?Maximizing (rather than minimizing) the agony of my unexpected affliction.Catch my drift, proverbial reader?Still Alice is profoundly sad, but not 'depressing.''Depressing' connotes a residual effect; a lasting (potentially irrevocable) alteration of your emotional state.I discourage this aversion toward cinematic tragedy. My top three films of all time (Platoon, Raging Bull and Schindler's List) belong in the downer category.Tragedy often spotlights hidden profundities.Still Alice is a heartwarming narrative obscured by the haze of Early Onset Alzheimer's, a rare form of the disease. Symptoms typically begin showing in the early fifties.At that precise moment, the viewer meets Alice and her family.It's tough, folks.No sugarcoating it.Expect to weep. More than once.On a high note, it's well shot, directed and edited. The writing's crisp; the drama's chilly and real.Lead by an outstanding performance from one of the best actresses ever, Julianne Moore, the entire cast is fantastic.Alec Baldwin's excellence in a major supporting role comes as no surprise.What (perhaps) defies expectation is an equally terrific piece of acting from Kristen Stewart.This reviewer hopped aboard Kristen's locomotive after Snow White and The Huntsman. That gal's gotten a bum rap, despite some serious acting chops.Anyhow. For an educational and moving experience, check out Still Alice.It's a top quality flick, featuring adept performances from a tight (but stellar) cast.Should one find oneself sobbing mid-theater, cursing a favorite film reviewer's name, try to remind oneself:"It's a mechanism of empathy, dawg."Feel that cognitive waterwheel aturnin'.

STILL ALICE is brilliantly delicate and disturbing story about a woman at the height of her intellectual powers who is diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's Disease. Julianne Moore is excellent as Alice as she slowly succumbs to the steady progress of her condition which wipes out her personality. Alec Baldwin is understated as her husband and, surprisingly, Kristen Stewart (Twilight) is excellent as Alice's daughter who connects with her mother more than anyone else in the family. This is the first movie (according to the director) which looks at Alzheimer's through the eyes of the person experiencing it. It's a must see that is confronting in its understated handling of a very difficult subject.

A tragic and moving performance by Julianne Moore is the cornerstone of the delicate and moving film that is Still Alice. A film constructed purely around Moore's performance (to its detriment) and would collapse without her, Moore's subtle work with the delicate script is sensitive and impressive enough to justify the film as an artwork.

Julianne Moore gives a very understated performance as a woman trying to deal with losing the very core of herself and becoming a shell of a woman. Good performances all around (even KStew), and some great gripping moments.

C'est le cas ici, grace en soit rendue aux acteurs formidables dont l'eminente Julianne Moore qui peut passer a la caisse sans honte pour recevoir son oscar comme Tom Hanks en son temps...

This is seemingly the story of a woman diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's disease, but around the midway-point of the film, this all becomes a lachrymose mess and it becomes increasingly clear that the real narrative of "Still Alice" is that of an actress who keeps a movie afloat for an hour and forty-five minutes. Julianne Moore is that actress, and she joins a class of performers (Jeff Bridges in "Crazy Heart," Meryl Streep in "Julie and Julia," etc.) who have turned borderline-bad-movies into something actually fairly watchable. That, I'm afraid, is the best that can be said of the film, which is numbing in its sentimentality and only really watchable for the acting; there are also good supporting turns from Alec Baldwin and, yes, even Kristen Stewart, who has some surprisingly nice moments. But the movie belongs to Moore, who is endlessly-engaging in her portrayal of a happy, brilliant woman who begins to lose that which is most precious to her. Her earnestness and fearfulness are enough to keep one engaged and, on several occasions, even tear up. There are moments of real elevation in "Still Alice," but they all belong to her.

Excellent!

Watching someone disintegrate on screen will never be 'fun' viewing, but it can be extremely moving and richly rewarding. Still Alice is such a film thanks to the incredible performance of the singular actor Julianne Moore. Moore plays Alice, an extremely gifted Columbia professor who is diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's. The film follows her path as her life falls apart, supported by her dedicated family. Moore tackles the role with nuance where needed and rage where required, giving us a great insight into her condition and also giving us a travel guide through human emotions and failings. It's inevitably sad but also strongly emotionally connected.

Inherently flawed due to its deliberate decision to refrain from becoming as dark as it could have been, Still Alice even then still manages to be an emotionally raw piece of work by the strength of Julianne Moore's performance, while the rest of the film merely manages to support the framework for her to thrive.

Still Alice is a drama film based on the novel of the same name by neuroscientist Lisa Genova. The film stars Julianne Moore as Dr. Alice Howland, who learns that she has Alzheimer's disease at the age of 50. Alice struggles to manage the time she has with her memory intact before she forgets everyone she cares about. Still Alice also stars Alec Baldwin, Kristen Stewart, Kate Bosworth, and Hunter Parish.This is another movie that didn't catch my eye until recently, getting word about Moore's performance in the film shortly before she was nominated for an Academy Award. Being one of the two movies with the Best Lead Actress nomination I haven't seen (the other one being Two Days, One Night with Marion Cotillard), I decided to see the movie to figure out if Moore's performance was truly as praiseworthy as most people say it is. As I expected, Julianne Moore was nothing short of amazing.There's no denying that the best thing about the movie by far is Julianne Moore's performance. Given how character driven the story is, the entire movie is dependent on Julianne's performance-and she is phenomenal. Her character's mental degeneration as she forgets more and more is virtually seamless. Before I saw this film, the best female performance of this 2014 in my opinion was Rosamund Pike in Gone Girl; I now say that Moore will most likely win the Oscar instead. My judgment with this boils down to two reasons, one being the fact that Moore had a much bigger role in terms of plot, and the other reason being that I find portrayals of people with any sort of disability to be exceptionally impressive when done well (like Eddie Redmayne's performance in The Theory of Everything). I wasn't sure whether to put this as a positive or a negative, due to circumstances, but the supporting characters failed to catch up to Moore's performance, making the film feel lop-sided in that aspect. This is in no way a criticism of any of the supporting actors, but the movie is Alice's show, and it is very clear that any distracting performances wouldn't be of best interest. There is even an otherwise regular scene of dialogue, which is entirely a close up of Alice with the other character off-screen, and it doesn't seem weird due to her prominent presence. This situation reminded me of Ben Affleck's performance in Gone Girl. Affleck's performance may have not been as big of a presence (figuratively speaking) as Pike's performance, but I believe this worked to the movie's favor.Interesting enough, this is the first movie featuring Kristen Stewart, who plays Alice's daughter who is a stage actor, I've seen in years. Because of this, I wasn't really exposed to movies like Twilight or Snow White and the Huntsman, in which many have criticized her acting ability. I wouldn't consider her performance terrible (except her in-movie theater performance), but I wish her performance were a little better. Again, this might just be the fact that most of her scenes are one-on-one conversations with the best performer in the movie. Other than that, I liked being able to stare at Stewart for a lot of the movie. Another thing I had trouble with was the ending. I feel like they either should have ended the movie before they did or added 10-15 more minutes.After seeing this movie, I'm confident that Moore is the frontrunner for Best Lead Actress. I also realized how some of my comments about the movie could also be applied to Gone Girl, although I personally enjoyed the latter more overall. If for nothing else, check this movie out for Moore's Oscar-worthy performance.7.5/10
A fascinating film, and quite a tear jerker.I would compare it to Bette Davis in Dark Victory (1939).

How irony is that this film is distributed by Sony Classic (they had a very good year in 2014 by the way) yet watching the film made me feel like watching a 1h39 advertisement of Apple, where Apple products and Apple products alone can save the day (speaking from a MacAir owner). This film is just above average, since everything were just half-done - half-done drama, half-done feel-good story, half-done character development, half-done style, half-done message, etc. The acting, except for Julianne Moore and Alec Baldwin, was terrible - Kate Bosworth looked annoying while Kristen "Stoneface" Steward still exhibited her infamous stone-face throughout the film. As a character-driven film, this is also another half-done aspect, since Baldwin did excel in his role as a matter-of-fact husband who loves his wife just barely more than his career as scientist, and Julianne Moore, well, she was just as excellent (yes, excellent!) in this film as in other films. The problem with Julianne Moore is that the ... half-done script really did not help her, some parts she appeared to be a woman of strong will, in other parts her behaviour resembled the behaviour of a loving wife and caring mother, yet those parts were not connected smoothly enough to bring out a complete picture of a woman falling into the abyss of forgetfulness. Julianne Moore has proven time and time again that she is an excellent actress of utmost mental sensitivity and emotional vulnerability. These strengths are both showed in this film, but to see Moore at her best of emotional vulnerability - "Magnolia" is a much better choice, whereas "Boogie Nights" is the best example of her mental sensitivity. That said, she may still get an Oscar for this role, but that would be an undeserved Oscar for a well-deserved career.
Absolutely perfect. Amazing film and performance. Kristen Stewart was a revelation. Juilianne was remarkable as always.

A raw portrait of a family divided by bad circumstance, Still Alice explore the life of Alice, an intelligent and successful professor who develops a rare form of early Alzheimer's. The tumultuous journey of deterioration is brutal, with fantastic performances from all around. Julianne Moore is obviously the stand out, but I feel some of the others also match her. View the mighty return of Kate Bosworth, Kristen Stewart under-used, and Alec Baldwin as one of the film's highlights. Though it doesn't give a lot of resolution, the movie is heart breaking but never manipulative, which is refreshing.

Julianne Moore is the center of STILL ALICE and it is her lack of all artifice that makes STILL ALICE quite powerful. The film is directly about alzheimers but ultimately about the loss of self that disease hurdles upon its victims. It's a terrifying film that induces tears because it is so matter of fact and not shy about those facts. If Moore is wonderful, Kristen Stewart is quite a revelation. She brings a depth and truth to her role as Moore's daughter which the other actors simply cannot deliver. And hence the problem with STILL ALICE. For all it's remarkable directness, STILL ALICE cannot resist a cliche and those cliches undermine far too much of the excellent work.
unforgettable performance by Julianne Moore!!!!

Not my slice of pie. I'll probably be in the minority of not liking this film, but it just didn't work for me. Alice Howland (Julianne Moore), is a renowned linguistics professor who teaches at Columbia. She is happily married to her successful husband John (Alec Baldwin), and has three grown kids: her daughter Anna (Kate Bosworth) who's trying to have kids, her son Tom (Hunter Parrish) who is going through med school, and then her more rebellious daughter Lydia (Kristen Stewart) who is in LA being an actor. One day Alice starts forgetting words and goes to see a doctor about her sudden memory lapse. She soon finds out that she has Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease. The rest of the movie follows her through the months of her slowly unraveling and what it does to her. Overall, thats about it. The movie gets the premise through to you in the first 15 minutes and from there it's an hour and a half of watching someone basically slowly lose all functionality. I just never felt connected to any of the characters expect strangely enough Stewart's character Lydia who seems to the most real out of everyone. John seems like an asshole who trys, but seems to always be going somewhere, or thinking of himself. Tom is a nobody. And then Anna comes off as a straight bitch at times. Moore does a good job playing Alice and is the clear favorite for Best Actress this year in the Academy Awards...but I am puzzled why. At times it seems like she's over acting and it clearly makes this film look just like Oscar Bait. Overall, I didn't enjoy this. It's a sad story and it really sucks to have Alzheimer's Disease and I can only pray I never have to experience it with my own family, or myself, but I just didn't like this one. It's a film I will watch once and never again. If you're super super interested then give it a look while it's in limited release. It not...you're really not missing much in my opinion!

Amazing film! Just brilliant! Julianne Moore is really amazing in this movie! I wrote an entire review talking about how wonderful this film is and then it got deleted, so I am tired and don't want to write it again, but this is AN AMAZING MOVIE and Julianne Moore deserves an award for her role!

Definitely a film where the actors carry the story. Julianne Moore certainly deserves her award nominations, and surprisingly even Kirsten Stewart is quite good in this. The story, for those who are unaware, is about Moore's Alice dealing with early onset Alzheimer's, and her coping with the condition. However, that is literally all there is to the story, and as a result other aspects of the film which are brought up are underdeveloped. Moore's and to a lesser extent Stewart's, characters are the only ones with some depth to them. A plot point about her variant being genetic is only briefly touched on, with her pregnant-with-twins oldest daughter (Kate Bosworth) testing positive for the markers but then no further discussion of it occurs. Moore reads a speech she wrote to Stewart, who comments it's too scientific which results in an argument, but then the speech given doesn't match the earlier one, so I'm not sure if Moore re-wrote it or if Stewart helped. Certainly worth seeing for the performances, and it brought back some memories of relatives of mine who had the disease, but don't be surprised if it leaves you wishing there was slightly more to the story.

The film is about losing oneself and the memories accumulated throughout life. It rests on the broad shoulders of utterly dependable, Julianne Moore who gives another towering performance. Though thats not a surprise but its about time she is recognised for her talent. Respect!!

What a brilliant performance by Julianne Moore. I thought it was very realistic and the writers did a great job of showing how others react to her changing. I also thought that the varying reactions from her children in the movie were also very realistic. I'm sure this movie will educate many families who are facing the same thing. It's finally time for Julianne to win her Oscar. No competition this year with this performance.

If Julianne Moore wins her first Oscar for STILL ALICE, it is not because the Academy thinks it is making up for snubbing her the last four times, but it will be because she earned it. Moore gives a heartbreaking performance as a middle-aged woman with Alzheimer's. It is so sad to just see her character, who is a smart, college professor, lose her memory to the point where she can't even spell "water". The movie itself is non-eventful as there really isn't any conflict besides Alice's disease. Kristen Stewart has some god scenes with Moore as her daughter, but there isn't enough of those scenes, because the two were great together. Julianne Moore has always done great work, but this performance might be the one that finally gets her the recognition she deserves.Grade: A-

Whoa give Julianne Moore the Oscar please. Still Alice is a thoroughly engaging and heartbreaking film that exceeds its seemingly disease TV movie trappings and makes for an emotionally intimate film with beautiful performances. One of the top ten films of 2014. Rating: 93

A heartbreaking and all-too-real drama that focuses on a rare form of Alzheimer's and the tragic loss-of-self that someone with so much left to live for experiences. Julianne Moore is phenomenal and this may be her best performance to date with emotional subtlety and a tear-enducing speech about what it is to lose your identity and her hopes for a cure. The brutal irony of a linguistics professor losing the ability to communicate is ripe with tragedy and watching her character's brain slowly degenerate isn't easy. Another stand-out is a surprisingly great turn from Kristen Stewart, whose strained relationship with her mother is resolved when she steps up to the plate to look after her. The film has a truly suspenseful moment that I won't spoil but my mouth was hanging open and I almost couldn't watch. The writing is strong, with small details of her coping mechanisms shining through such as a daily quiz and in her aforementioned speech; highlighting each line so she doesn't repeat herself are wonderful additions to the realistic nature of the film. Julianne Moore did an amazing job and I applaud the blunt approach the filmmakers took to an increasingly terrifying disease that I found highly relatable.

A heartbreaking true story showing the sheer destructive nature of Alzheimers. With some truly sad scenes, Julianne Moore gives a superb performance showing how utterly powerless we are to the mercy of disease.

Well, just hand Julianne Moore the golden statue. She deserves it. Although her performance is heartbreaking, this movie is structured like a Lifetime movie. An Oscar-caliber Lifetime movie, but still a Lifetime movie. But Julianne as Alice will wreck you as she deteriorates.

A tremendously searing performance from Moore, "Still Alice" wears the veil of a Lifetime "disease-of-the-week" movie, but it surpasses the genre conventions into something more intimate and emotionally powerful. There are moments of true beauty, as Moore is not willing to submit to her life-long disease, as she is actively doing her best to thwart her ailments. Then the moments of pure sadness perforate the viewer with enough conviction from both the performances and direction that it leaves the viewer on a very unpleasant, but affirming note.

Julianne Moore gives an astounding and emotionally powerful performance in 'Still Alice'. The movie itself is being under rated, I loved the first hour, but the ending is too abrupt, I wanted more time. Despite an intrusive score, 'Still Alice' explores it's tough subject matter with respect. Moore gets great support by the much maligned (unfairly) Kristen Stewart. Their scenes together are true and touching. 'Still Alice' stays away from Lifetime movie status due to Julianne Moore's much deserved Oscar nominated performance.

Because of Julianne Moore's performance is so powerful that this movie is tough to watch. But it is an excellent study in having to let go of your identity, which is a part of aging that one doesn't grasp until it starts to happen.

A thoughtful and poignant film about Alzheimer's, a gut-wrenching and savage disease, tip-toes ever so slightly into PSA territory. Luckily, the fearless portrayal of Alice by Julianne Moore, one of our finest actresses, keeps the film grounded and honest. Directors Glazer and Westmoreland honor Alice and the film's subject matter with grace, allowing the audience a sense of disorientation through excellent cinematography, consistent reflective visuals, and a stunning use of camera focus. One can't imagine the film any differently, but it certainly doesn't feel that the journey completes, that the story ever really peaks, or that we can be sure of what to do with how we feel about it...then again, maybe that's the point.

A thoughtful and poignant film about Alzheimer's, a gut-wrenching and savage disease, tip-toes ever so slightly into PSA territory. Luckily, the fearless portrayal of Alice by Julianne Moore, one of our finest actresses, keeps the film grounded and honest. Directors Glazer and Westmoreland honor Alice and the film's subject matter with grace, allowing the audience a sense of disorientation through excellent cinematography, consistent reflective visuals, and a stunning use of camera focus. One can't imagine the film any differently, but it certainly doesn't feel that the journey completes, that the story ever really peaks, or that we can be sure of what to do with how we feel about it...then again, maybe that's the point.
An insightful film with a heartbreakingly touching performance by Julianne Moore.

Still Alice, based on the by Lisa Genova, dives into the life of 50-year-old Dr. Alice Howland (Julianne Moore), a successful cognitive psychologist at Columbia University, who is diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's disease. Alice begins to forget small things -- like the words to an important speech and where she is in her neighborhood -- which prompts her to see a neurologist. The film then follows Alice as she struggles to hold on to what has defined her for most of her adult life: her family and her job. Julianne Moore's gripping, honest, and devastating portrayal of Alice's decline defines the film. Her subtle yet powerful depiction of Alice captures the anguish and confusion of losing control over your actions and thoughts and, eventually, losing your identity.

Beautifully understated movie with amazing acting prowess exhibited by the underrated Julianne Moore. If you were looking for a light-hearted feel-good romp, this movie is not for you. Easily becoming the Philadelphia (Tom Hanks) of this decade, this first-person view of Alzheimer's disease makes you feel warm on the inside while reducing you to a hot mess on the outside.
A brave film about illness that is often a difficult watch, but in all necessity. Julianne Moore may very well deserve to take home her Oscar this year.

Grand in its details, Still Alice provides a welcome vehicle for its star, as well as the supporting cast. Heart-felt, honest, and well paced, Still Alice is expertly executed and wholly moving, without slipping into melodrama.

"Still Alice" is one of those films that was significant before ever being released to theaters. This depiction of early onset Alzheimer's disease is truthful, heartbreaking, and something that we should all see. Many films have tackled the physical destruction caused by cancer and AIDS, but this film offers an unadulterated look at Alzheimer's degenerative destruction of the mind. "Still Alice" explores the emotional suffering of a college linguistics professor as she quickly loses her words, memory, and ability to function; moreover, it shows the devastating consequences on her family as her mind disappears. This film is particularly difficult because it centers around a loving marriage and a tight-knit family. It shatters our image of "happily ever after" in lieu of reality. The success of the film hinges completely on Julianne Moore, and her performance is inspired. After four previous Oscar nominations, this has to be Moore's year to take home Best Actress. The contrast between subtle and dynamic emotional reactions paints the picture of a woman whose soul is at war with her mind. There is a unique emotional topography as her emotions magnify as she comes to terms with the disease and then slowly diminish as the disease takes over her mind. Her emotional collapse is physically reflected by her facial expressions as they transform from being full of life to blank. Of course, the rest of the cast supports the emotionally-charged story. Alec Baldwin shakes off his typical goofball persona to portray the frustrations of losing your wife emotionally while remaining the loyal caregiver. While some people might question the inclusion of Kristen Stewart into this cast, she isn't bad. Her character lacks emotion but Moore's performance is so stunning that you won't even remember that Kristen Stewart was in it. You need to emotionally prepare yourself for this film. There is not a silver lining and the reality of this disease is tough to swallow. But "Still Alice" drives home an important message about life: rather than valuing money or success, value your memories. Alzheimer's victims spend each day treasuring each memory, knowing that it could be the last time that they ever get to remember it.
